title: Foxnews quit working correctly in Firefox
content: Been using Firefox for years. Also reading Foxnews. Starting yesterday I cannot post any comments at the site. I can go to Edge and all works fine, so there is something with Firefox that is conflicting with Foxnews. At first I was not able to even read articles but removed all Addon's and that has been fixed--even after reinstalling all Addon's I can still read articles. I log into my Fox account and the webpage reflects that but when I try to post a comment it says I must sign in to post, yet I am signed in! However, I go ahead and follow the links to sign in (check e-mail/click sign in to Fox etc.), ultimately it tells me I'm now signed in. But when I go back to the comment section it still says I must sign in to post but I am signed in. Besides removing Addon's I also tried removing the FF browser (Win 10 recommended a refresh instead of uninstall so I did that). No help, I'm thinking whatever is causing the conflict when refreshing FF the sync simply puts the conflict back! I'm still requested to sign in when I am signed in! As stated earlier my Fox account in MS Edge works fine.
creator: wingrider6

title: Return to previously used window when you close fullscreen window
content:
I am on mac, and when ever I open a new firefox window while I am on full screen and then close the new window I am being returned to the main desktop instead of the window I used to be on.

I tried with with other app - chrome, safari, vscode and I with another account with no pref. change on my mac or on firefox and the same thing is happening. I tried with and w/o extension, removing my profile, and a fresh install and still the same thing is happening and it so annoying. How can I fix this ?

this is really frustrating, I would like to get a better "reading" of what happens, as an Engineer I am happy to also squint at logs if needed, please consider adding a preference / settings change log file
creator: looeegee

title: How to efficiently display VideoFrames
content:
Hi there,

apologies if this is not the right forum for a developer question, but Bugzilla didn't fell quite right in my case.

I'm developing a video streaming application that has to work with a custom streaming protocol. I already have an implementation using VideoDecoder and Insertable Streams that works in Chrome. Encoded VPX frames are being efficiently decoded and piped into an HTMLVideoElement via the MediaStreamTrack API. My understanding is that Firefox will soon have support for VideoDecoder (you can already enable it as an experimental feature and it works fine), but insertable streams is something that Firefox will not implement because it favors RTCRtpScriptTransform. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

Could you point me to a way how to efficiently get a VideoFrame that I got from a VideoDecoder into an HTMLVideoElement without a MediaStreamTrackGenerator (part of the insertable streams API which Firefox will not implement)? I've already tried:

  • drawing to a canvas (instead of video element)
  • wrapping the (still encoded) vpx frames in a WebM container and using it with a MediaSource SourceBuffer (with a video element)

Both attempts worked in Firefox, but performance was nowhere near the Insertable Streams way.

The VideoDecoders work very well in both Chrome and Firefox (with WebCodecs API enabled) according to my benchmarks. It's really just the matter of getting the decoded frame displayed where I can't find an efficient solution for Firefox.

Thanks a lot in advance!

If this is the wrong forum, could you please refer me to a more appropriate place?
creator: maradus

title: Scheduling an appointment on the Safelite website in Firefox crashes my computer
content:
If I go to Safelite and start scheduling an appointment, navigating through that set of webpages will cause my computer to green screen/crash. The landing page at https://safelite.com asks for a zip code, and submitting that form puts you into the scheduling flow; after entering some details about a vehicle, I can click back and continue a few times (less than ten) to make my computer crash. I was able to reproduce the issue in troubleshooting mode. I also tried the same steps in Chrome, but it did not produce a crash.

This computer has had an issue with crashing in this manner for a while now, but this is the first thing I've noticed consistently causes a crash. I'm not expecting a solution, but I am hoping to close in on the issue; whether or not Firefox is the source here is questionable, but it does seem highly entangled.
creator: drgn170

title: how to edit URL pulldown?
content: Is it possible to customize the URL pulldown? When I click in the URL window - I am presented with 6 website options along with various web search options. It would be helpful to modify the options since none of them apply to me. I tried deleting history, playing with the settings/search suggestions/change settings. I want to specify certain websites - and leave it that way. I've tried right clicking the site, shift deleting, contrl deleting. Nothing works. If it is possible - it is not intuitive. I notice that the list does slowly seem to update and evolve depending on where I have been. But I don't want that either. Thx IW

creator: gpen50

title: Firefox crashes in one account but not another
content:
I'm running Firefox 121.0 on Windows 11 Pro 23H2. I have two accounts, A & B, on my PC. A is the default Administrator account, B is a regular administrator account. I have no problems whatsoever running Firefox in account B. Account A is a different story. As soon as I launch Firefox, its windows appears and immediately freezes up. Mouse doesn't move, Ctrl-Alt-Del doesn't work. I can do nothing but wait. After waiting for a few minutes, the blue death screen appears. I have to restart the PC.

Since Firefox runs fine in account B, I don't think the system has any problem. I ran SFC anyway. As expected, it reported no problems.

It seems this might be a registry problem or something that is specific to the setting of account A. I guess I could uninstall and re-install Firefox but wonder if anyone ever encountered the same problem and have a solution.
creator: user169553241690584565946990492931326253514

title: Firefox has taken over PDFs
content: In the last few days whenever I download a PDF file instead of it being displayed in my default PDF read Firefox (version 121.0.1) takes over and displays the contents of the file. I do not want this, I prefer my PDF reader! How do I stop Firefox trying to take over this function? (other than converting to Chrome)
